keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a vehicle it struck.
The Boeing aircraft, arriving from Dubai, broke in two upon exiting the runway, with the tail section snapped off and the front section severely damaged.
The aircraft did not indicate any distress on approach; no emergency requests were received from pilots.
The two occupants of the airport security patrol car were killed when the plane collided with it and pushed it into the sea.
Four crew members on board were treated for injuries and confirmed safe; no cargo was on board.
The flight was operated under an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides extra cargo capacity to major airlines.
The airport suspended operations on its north runway until the aircraft is retrieved; two other runways remain operational, so over 1,000 daily flights are not disrupted.
More than 200 people, fire engines, and boats were involved in the emergency response.
Hong Kong International Airport has a history of rare fatal aviation accidents, including a 1999 incident involving a China Airlines flight that landed upside down during a typhoon.
The former Kai Tak Airport, located in densely populated Kowloon, was historically considered one of the world’s most difficult airports to land at.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines, flying under an Emirates flight number and wet-leased from ACT, skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) during arrival from Dubai around 3:50 a.m. local time. The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon exiting the runway, colliding with an airport security patrol car and pushing it into the sea, killing two occupants. No distress signals were reported by the pilots. Four crew members on board were treated for injuries and are confirmed safe. The airport suspended operations on its north runway, though other runways remain active, minimizing flight disruptions. The incident is rare at HKIA, which has a history of only a few fatal accidents, including a 1999 crash involving a China Airlines flight. The former Kai Tak Airport, once known for its challenging landing conditions, is referenced in context of the airport's operational history.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
